title: Women as nurses were involved in the battlefields early
description: When the war broke up, many women went to the battlefields... as nurses. That was the case of Marie Louise Boets, who voluntereed in the west front. Nursing in World War One was exhausting, often dangerous work and those women experienced the horror of war firsthand, some paying the ultimate price.

title: A dutch mother and grandmother are held in captivity by the Germans
description: During World War I, about 8 million men surrendered and were held in POW (Prisoner of War) camps until the war ended. All nations pledged to follow the Hague rules on fair treatment of prisoners of war, and in general the POWs had a much higher survival rate than their peers who were not captured. Also women, like these young woman and her daughter, end up in captivity.

title: Working in an obus producing factory as a woman
description: Munitionettes worked with hazardous chemicals on a daily basis without adequate protection. They worked . Due to the highest risk of this profession, munitionnettes got the highest wages at the time. However, they were paid less than men (50% less in 1913 and 20% less in 19,177) for the same work.

title: Temporary women workers driving to work at the Western front
description: Following the outbreak of World War I in 1914, the German Army opened the Western Front by first invading Luxembourg and Belgium, then gaining military control of important industrial regions in France. Between 1915 and 1917 there were several major offensives along this front. The attacks employed massive artillery bombardments and massed infantry advances. However, a combination of entrenchments, machine gun nests, barbed wire, and artillery repeatedly inflicted severe casualties on the attackers and counterattacking defenders. As a result, no significant advances were made. In an effort to break the deadlock, this front saw the introduction of new military technology, including poison gas, aircraft and tanks.

title: The woman who killed ""tens of thousands of soldiers""
description: Margaretha Geertruida Zelle, better known by Mata Hari, has been one of the most famous spies ever. She was convicted of espionage for Germany and of being responsible of causing the death of thousands of soldiers. This is Ms. Mata Hari at the day of her arrest, on 13 February 1917, little before she was executed by firing squad in France

title: Women of Britain Say 'Go!'
description: As the conflict progressed, more men were required in the front. Propaganda for the British Army recruitment campaign is indicative of the increasingly sophisticated and commercialised strategies employed by recruiters to encourage the British male to enlist. It also shows how calls for mobilization were adressed to women as well.

title: Emma Siepermann: women in trousers
description: Trousers have been largely worn by men and not by women until the early 20th century. During World War I, women Ьike Emma Siepermann, in the photoРwore their husbands' trousers while they took on jobs previously assigned to men.

title: Austrian soldiers playing football to collect money for Austrian widows
description: Over 15,000,000 men died during the First World War: it was a 'lost generation' of young men. Many women lost their husband, so kitty activities were often organised to support these widows. Other women in this period remained single by choice or by financial necessity. Professions such as teaching and medicine were opening up to women, but only if they remained unmarried.
copyright: Wienbibliothek im Rathaus, Sammlung, Signatur, www.digital.wienbibliothek.at

title: In the name of mercy, give!
description: With the outbreak of World War I, the Red Cross found itself confronted with enormous challenges. Red Cross nurses from around the world came to support the medical services of the armed forces of the European countries involved in the war. This poster was one of many in order to support the activities of the organization. In 1917, the ICRC would receive the Nobel Peace Prize for its outstanding wartime work.

title: The munitionettes
description: With men engaged in the front, munitions industry found itself having difficulty producing the amount of weapons and munition needed by the Army. To put an end to this Shell Crisis of 1915, factories were forced to admit more women as employees. They were called the ""munitionettes"" (picture from Vickers Limited factories)

title: Working at the factory
description: Although women in paid employment did exist before the First World War, they were mainly concentrated in textile manufacture. The lost of a substantial part of the industrial menforce engaged the women in new jobs and took them out from the traditional home-sphere. In this photo, female workers deplate male work force at Churchill's Pendleton factory, where a specialist knowledge in the heat treatment of metals was demanded.

title: Women in the shipbuilding industry
description: At the beginning of the war, women were mostly engaged in industries related to war. ""Munitionnettes"" were the most known, but women were also found in the ship industry. This woman was employed by Palmers Shipbuilding & Iron Company Limited to move timber around their shipyard at Hebburn-on-Tyne.

title: Female crowds at work
description: A crowd of women workers taking a break to look at the camera as they stand or sit beside their benches at a gas mask factory in Holloway, London. Their typing machines can be seen on the benches in front of them.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Also in Coal Mines
description: Women pit brow workers of the Wigan Coal and Iron Company, 1918. These women sorted coal and moved heavy tubs on the surface of a coal mine Рwork that was dirty and physically demanding. Jobs like these had been done by working class women before the war and continued to be important in wartime.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Experience of German female prisoners
description: Women from both sides were captivated, their experiences were written down and shall not be forgotten.

title: Working in a munition factory
description: At the beginning of the war, few women integrated arm factories of Western countries. In 1915, when the need for shells intensified, women were brought into munitions manufacturing in large numbers. By 1918 almost a million british women and 400,000 french women were employed in some aspect of munitions work, and they produced roughly 80% of the weaponry and ammunition used by their armies. Here, women workers in Woolwich, Arsenal
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Women sit crowded to produce gas masks
description: A general view of the central hall of Crowndale Works, an anti-gas mask factory, in Camden Town, London. A mass of women sit shoulder to shoulder on long tables to prepare the glass for the mask eyepieces.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: An important call upon the women of Britain
description: World War I was the first time that aircraft were used on a large scale. Aeroplanes were just coming into military use at the outset of the war, an d their impact was mainly tactical rather than strategic. Initially, they were used mostly for reconnaissance. Pilots and engineers learned from experience, leading to the development of many specialized types, which were built in factories like this.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: The ladies at work
description: Baking biscuits at an army biscuit factory in Lancashire. These distinctive hard biscuits were an important staple of the rations for British soldiers during the war. While they tended to be unpopular with soldiers due to their hard texture, they provided useful nutrition in a form that was almost indestructible.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: New relationships in the factory
description: Working in industry could be hard, monotonous and sometimes dangerous, but there was also a strong sense of camaraderie amongst workers. Wartime conditions saw a greater variety of opportunities for women.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Gas mask production
description: World War I was the first were chemical weapons, such as tear gas or mustard gas, were used. Chemical warfare was a major component of the first global war of the 20th century. The killing capacity of gas, however, was limited, and they were primarily used to demoralize, injure, and kill entrenched defenders. Development of gas protection was a big process during the period which progressed to increasingly effective gas masks.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: All aboard the transport industry
description: One of the areas of employment where new opportunities opened up for women was in transport. Women began working as bus conductresses, ticket collectors, porters, carriage cleaners and bus drivers. During the war the number of women working on the railways rose from 9,000 to 50,000. While new jobs did become available to women during wartime, many of these opportunities were closed to them after the war as servicemen returned to their jobs
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: The First World War was fought on a huge industrial scale.
description: With men recruited for the armed forces, the industrial workforce changed. From the munitions factory to laboratories to the coal mine, women held all kind of men-traditional-jobs during the First World War.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Frieda's diary
description: Frieda, a young woman, writes about longing for nature and her hometown after the war.

title: Women wanted
description: Women's Army Auxiliary Corps was a branch of the British military in the First World War. Over 7,000 women served between January 1917 and November 1918, helping in the daily life of military camps.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: The first women police officers served during the First World War
description: The first women police officers served during the First World War. One of the main responsibilities of the Womenճ Patrols - as they were initially known - was to maintain discipline and monitor womenճ behaviour around factories or hostels. They also carried out inspections of women to ensure that they did not take anything into the factories which might cause explosions. As is shown here, they also patrolled other public areas such as railway stations, streets, parks and public houses.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Women workers dealing with hazardous material
description: Women workers producing asbestos mattresses. Whilst appreciated as a hazardous material today, asbestos was used in a range of wartime products such as mattresses used to line the boilers of battleships.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Lab workers
description: Women at work in the laboratory of Brunner, Mond & Co in Northwich, a company that manufactured sodium bicarbonate. Sometimes known as baking soda, sodium bicarbonate was used for baking and a range of other purposes. Women at the factory did a variety of jobs, from scientific lab work to packaging the finished produc
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence.

title: Women nurses desperately needed after the end of WWI
description: At the end of the war, women progressively abandonned the factories and were specially requested for ""traditional"" tasks. Childcare -for children of those working women- and nursing were highly demanded. In this poster, thousands of women between the ages of 18 and 55 are wanted.
copyright: This item is available to share and reuse under the terms of theIWM Non Commercial Licence

title: A special call for women mobilization
description: ""Appel aux Femmes Franaises"" (Call to French Women) was a speech by Ren Viviani meant to mobilization. As long as men were in the battlefields, women were requested to take their labours. This way, the ""total war"" started, since all the population was involved in the war effort.

title: Letter from Lon to his wife
description: Leon was a soldier in the 146th infantery, stationed in Bois-le-Ptre (France), where he ultimately died for the fatherland.

title: The story of a pilot who became MIA on 26/09/1918
description: The reconaissance pilot Richard Scholl, his plane of the type Hannover CL II, his equipment and other members of his unit who became missed in action on the 26/09/18.

title: American soldiers in Piave
description: American soldiers on the Piave front hurling a shower of hand grenades into the Austrian trenches.

title: Funeral in Narajov
description: A funeral of fallen soldiers in Narajov.

title: A naval contingent marching in London at the end of World War I
description: A naval contingent marching in London at the end of the war.

title: New Zealand soldiers and civilians in London at the end of World War I
description: Not only European soldier were active during the Great War. A lot of soldier from colonies or commonwealth of European nation states joined the military forces in Europe.

title: Tea party at the Bristol Royal Infiermery
description: A tea party for injured soldiers recovering at the Bristol Royal In޲mary. The location is not given but the soldiers convalescing at the BRI were frequently taken on cruises to tea gardens on the Avon. In 1915 alone a total of 11.773 sick and wounded soldiers arrived in Bristol from the fronts in France, Belgium and Gallipoli.

title: Soldiers cleaning their uniforms themselves
description: WWI contributed to female emancipation, at home women had to work to care for their families, on the front soldiers had to clean their clothes themselves.

title: Soldier's comrades watching him as he sleeps
description: This is a very personal moment in his war experience. He is covered in dust while being in a probably uncofomfortable position.

title: Trip to Paris
description: German soldiers, some with flowers others waving or rasing their clenched fists, in a railroad car on the way to the front during early World War I . Messages on the car spell out (approximately): ""Trip to Paris"", ""See you later on the Boulevard"", ""[obscured by flowers] the fight"" (The obscured part most likely reads ""Auf in [den Kampf]"" which means ""Into battle""), ""my sword tip is itching"".

title: Indian soldiers are preparing for a gas attack
description: It is often forgotten many colonial soldiers joined the Allied forces. In the overall time span of World War I, approximately as many Indian as British soldiers have fallen.

title: Before the fight
description: French 87th Regiment Cote 34 Verdun

title: Fred C Palmer Wounded Soldiers WWI near Herne Bay
description: The soldiers based closest to Palmer's studio in 1914-1918 were The Buffs, (East Kent Regiment), which raised nine battalions in World War I. (Today the Buffs are amalgamated into the Princess of Wales's Royal Regiment.)

title: On the first day of Somme battle
description: Royal Irish Rifles in a communication trench during the first day of the Battle of Somme

title: Advancing at Vimy
description: Mark II female Tank Number 598 advancing with Infantry at Vimy

title: Serbs' execution
description: A World War I execution squad. Blindfolded and in a kneeling position, patriotic Jugo-Slavs in Serbia near the Austrian lines were arranged in a semi-circle and ruthlessly shot at a command.

title: Bulgarian soldiers
description: Bulgarian soldiers in position to fire against an incoming airplane.

title: Battle of Cambrai
description: German soldiers make preparations to recover a knocked out british MARK IV tank. The battle of Cambrai is often erroneously noted for being the first mass use of tanks in a combined arms operation.

title: Austro-Hungarian mountain corps
description:
The Italian Alpini, their Austrian counterparts (Kaiserjger, Standschtzen and Landesschtzen), and the German Alpenkorps occupied every hill and mountain top. Hundreds of troops would drag guns over mountains up to 3,890 m 
(12,760ʦt). Streets, cable cars, mountain railways and walkways through
the steepest of walls were built. The first to occupy higher ground 
became almost impossible to dislodge, so both sides turned to drilling 
tunnels under mountain peaks, filling them up with explosives, then 
detonating the entire mountain, including its defenders, such as Col di Lana,
Monte Pasubio, Lagazuoi, etc. Climbing and skiing became essential 
skills for the troops of both sides and soon Ski Battalions and Special 
Climbing units were formed.

title: The Battle of Doberdo
description:
The Battle of Doberd was one of the bloodiest battlefields of World War I, fought in August 1916 between the Italian and Austro-Hungarian Army, composed mostly of Hungarian and Slovenian regiments. Both sides had taken massive losses, with an estimated of more than 
20,000 soldiers killed or missing. Although victorious, Italian losses 
were much greater than those of the Austro-Hungarians, with around 5,000
of their soldiers killed. In all, this was a strategically important victory for the 
Italians despite the outcome of the battle.
